document.text: wondering why they spent the I month at books to become brides. And daring the summer there was I no cocking departm ent in opera -1 tion. Those girls and boys that went to Trenton had the times of their lives. Did you ever know of a fish-1 ing party that had a dull moment, I  bite or no bit j ? I have yet to hear j the best fish story born of the oc casion, but if I am fortum te enough to get it will pass it ou to you. 1 am looking to Mayor Blanton a the source of supply. No man en I I joys a fish, I mean the act of fishing, as he does. The editor of the Herald has the laugh on th s friend who offered him ten dollars to walk to the high, bridge after dark. The offer was promptly taken and he is waiting  for the nextm an with ten dollarstol invest in like enterprise. He says it was easy money. Ho would no I have, ventured out in a Btorm. Nothing new on the primary to decide the sergeantoy question. I The suggestion seemed to meet with I I favor but there the m atter ended. I We are to have fonr new oounoil men with the beginning of the new term, and neither one of the uum- I bar received a majority of the votes I cast at the primary. It is a mistake to say th at majorities always rule in this land of the free and of the G. O. P. Mr. and Mrs. D. T. Elam on their return from the Greenbriar W hite i Sulphur unite in saying of th atl ancient resort,  the gem of the I I mountain . Mr. Elam went so far I as to add th a t leaving the favored j spot for other resorts was  like go ing from parlor to cabin. A gentleman from South Caro lina d.ove over the Buckingham roads the other day and pronounced them the  worst in America. What ia wrong with the old county? There are more  holiness people in Buckingham than in Prinoe Ed-  ward, and anoh people should  look well to their ways. It may be th at they have more faith than the rest of ns and simply aught brighter visions of the coming airships when country roads would all fall into  innocnonsdesuetide. But we are not going that way as yet. Watermelons have been disap.. pointing bo far. Too muoh water to begin with, as I am told, and too I little to end with. And it did strike me that the peach season was slori lived. But like o her blessings they brighten as they took their I flight. Thanks to your contributor who answered my inquiry as to the meaning of Appomattox. As I grow I in y ars I get more and more onri-l ous to know the meaning of things, and yet mystery shfonds the way I and so many questions go un answered. I saw Cashier Yaiden at a picnic I the other day and he looked aa hap py as  a big sun flower. Doubt less he went through the day with out  protesting a thing th at he saw or heard. After a superb din ner I smoked one ol his fragrant Havannas and aa I smoked remem bered the couplet I learned in boy hood days  Anil when the smoke ascends on high, Then thou beholdst the vanity. Of worldy stuff. Gone with a puff. Thus think and amoke tobacco.

document.text: Williamsburg, Va.- Charles City County has become the first county in Virginia to set up a fund-raising project for the Jamestown Festival of 1957 andIsle of Wight County has become the first to contract for a historical restoration to be ex hibited beginning the year of the celebration. iH. C. Sledd, chairman of the Charles City Festival Committee, an nounced here yesterday that a special open house will be held by five fa mous plantations in the county on October 21, 22, 23 of this year to begin the fund-raising. The old county courthouse and jail will also be open to visitors. Each county or city that raises funds will spend them on its own attractions as it sees fit, and Mr. Sledd said that the nominal fees charged to visitors would go toward a fund to convert the old jail into an information and relic house dur ing the Festival and for exhibition thereafter. David A. Rawls, of Smithfield, chairman of the Isle of Wight Coun ty Festival Committee, said that the countys branch of the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities has contracted with the firm of Claiborne and Taylor, Rich mond, for restoration of the exterior walls of the circular courtroom of the old courthouse in Smithfield. The restoration fund of this APVA branch has been accumulating and is now sufficient to begin the work, Mr. Rawls said, but Isle of Wight, too, will set about raising money to complete the courthouse restoration by 1957. People of the county will be called upon to con tribute to the restoring of this two centuries-old attraction. Twenty-three ocunties, ten cities, and six colleges have appointed Fes tival committees, the Virginia 850th Anniversary Commission announced.

Mr. W. R Moore, who sold his farm in Buckingham and moved to Bedford oounty, was here to attend the Baptist As sociation, and he said he bad sold his place in Bedford and was thinking of returning to his old county to live. We will gladly welcome such a good man.

document.text: When the CarriageStopped He was To  Swelled  to Get Through the Door. Speaking of bumble-bees, said the Mayor, as he tilted his chair and derricked his feet on to the porch railing, reminds me of a funny thing that occurred up in Loui,sa county when I was a young man Before the war that was a fine old county, you know, and inost of the people lived like fighting-cocks, but soon after the late unpleasantness the hand of time bpgan to write Ichabod pretty., freely..oyer every thing, and the old county, with its good old families, was sadly changed There lived near us the Parkinson familyaud a first-rite family it was, tooa gay, household of sons and daughters there had been until marriage and death thinned the old house, and only the old doctor aud his wife, with one son, were left Bob, the remaining son, was a bril liant fellow, and as reckess as bril iiant. lie had a fine education being a gradnate in law at the Uni versity of Virginia, but he made no us of it, aud used to say, with waggish smile, that no man in Vir ginia practiced so faithfully as he did, only he practiced at the wrong bar. Poor fellow ? He could never look upon the wiue when ?twas red without imbiding too freely, and he was always half drunk, if not wholly

document.text: well, and many of our sturdy farm era wear a pleased, satisfied look. This old county is not going to I make an assignmentnot yet nor are we going to sell out and  move away, hunting for a land I where gold dollars hang on trees like crah apples and half dollars are as plentiful as potato bugs. See ? Our town is still improving. Dr.  J. F. Alsop has just completed a j handsome office on the block burn -1 ed last winter. Mr. Arthur Allen has enclosed bis property with a substantial fence. New Frink Reflectors have been put in Prospect Church, adding I much to the comfort and attractive ness of the auditorium. Miss Mary Bell, of Lynchburg, is I visiting her uncle, Rev. P. M. Bell. Mrs. Tom Walton, of West Appo-j mattox, is visting her sister, Mrs. James Lewis. Mrs. W. H. Walden has returned  from n extended visit to Rich mond, Crewe and Farmville. She I was accompanied on the trip by Master Jimmie Lewis. Master Allen Bell has about re-1 covered from bis hurt of five weeks  ago, but walks with a slight limp The gardens of our town are in I fine condition, and if the lamb was  obtainable, we could live on iht aristocratic diet of lamb and peas, j as it is we will have to be content with the common dish of peas and potatoes, at least until spring chick ens are ripe for plucking.

THE OR AND OLD COUNTY PtlOTÜ ORAPHED Mexican indolence haa always id fomething to do wfth   h i i national history, said a traveler. Mexico haa a class of natives called loaners front theirhabit of leaning acatnat the fide of a building to roll a cigarette. Once In this position  leaner adheres to It tor hour. Tradition declares that a m w I m  loaner once sued an Amerioan railroad builder for pulling down a building against which the plaintiff had been leaning. Damages were awarded tor severe shook and inconvenience, and the court took oooaaloa to recommend a law requiring one boos notice un der similar circumstances. Mexican military forces are to ome extent recruited from lsansrs. Mexican history h record of an! Insurgent tores which was being pushed forward victoriously when It oatoa to a stream which had swollen overnight The general was a leaner. Ha bivouacked to wait till the stream ehpuld subside, but It did not subside and b withdraw. Ha could easily hava bridged a narrow cascade leas  a mQe from his camp, but that would hava required fresh initiative, which hia no place In the practical philos ophy of a leaner. But he suoceeded, anyhow, because his adversary was also a leaner. When the river fell the Insurgent force cups back, crossed without op- Portion, and casually took possession of the oontected territory.

document.text: W ritten for the T imes . To appreciate the beauties of Oc tober one should seek the woods in early morning  for at this hour the fresh, dewy fragrance has lost none of its sweetness and the brilliant co lors of autumn are softened by the overhanging mists. The rising sun casts in slanting rays his bars of trembling light along the brown car peted -aisles of the forest, and the dewdrops clustering npon the lace work of cobwebs are transformed into so many sparkling gems. Nor is animation wanting. Birds, too, are chirping from every bush, the dead branches resound to the blows of the woodpecker, and squirrels leap in sportive glee from limb to limb. On such a morning and amid such a scene our story opensi- It was in the old county of Appo mattox in the South  5 iïfMi?fio Virginia, where, if other places are more populous and wealthy, cer tainly none is more beautiful and at tractive. The opening events oc curred in a body of woods not far from the little village of Oakville. A dilapidated rail fence ran along the border of the forest separating it from a field of stubble, in the midst of which stood a large log cabin. A little to the right and about a quar ter of a mile beyond could be seen the chimneys and a part of the build ing of that quaint and pretty place known as Beverly, the home of the Hon. Hugh Taylor or Hon. Hugh as he was usually designated. If you had called upon that gen tleman at this early hour, you would have been disappointed, for his ser vant would have informed yon that Mars Hugh was still in bed. But, strange to say, if yon had examined the woods very closely you would have discovered him leaning against a large white oak. And the huge tree towering towards the sky was a suit able symbol of himself  for he was a magnificent specimen of man hoodtall, straight as an arrow, short hut heavy beard, powerful limbs, head proudly poised between a grand pair of shoulders, and with a general appearance that betokened him to he a man of about forty years of age. With it all his face was sto lid and unintellectual, filled with good humor and dogged pertinacity. He was evidently waiting for some one, and when the door of the cabin was opened, and a young girl came out, he moved around to the other side of the tree so that he might watch unobserved. The Hon. Hugh thought that he had never seen a fairer sight. He likened the form approaching him to a fair-haired god dess of the woods coming to take pos session of her realms, the forest. Nor was his comparison inappropri ate. She was a flaxen-haired, dark eyed little maiden, who came grace fully tripping over the dewy stubble, and who, a long time before, had cap tured the heart of the dignified gen tleman behind the tree. She did not care if he had been twice a widower, she had proudly and gladly accepted his attentions and had promised to become his wife. He was the owner of a lordly mansion house and of thousands of acres of land, while she was poor insignificant Scotia Byrd, the daughter of one of his ten-

document.text: W est B uckingham . Dear A. and B. T imes As it has been some tim since I have seen anything from this quiet cor ner of the old county, 1 will give yon a few lines to let you and uur people know that we are still alive, Well Xmas. iB near at hand aud Madam Rumoi says that some of the Appomattox sons will soon de prive old Buckingham of some of her fair dcughters. All I have to say is to wish them much happiness We have had quite a dry fall at.d but little fallowing has been done up to this time. Hog killing has been the order of the day for the last few weeks in this section and 1 think the crop of meat is a good one. A good corn crop generally gives good crop of meat. Miss Rosa Wright is spending a few weeks in Richmond. Mr. J. T. Spencer and his son Ashley have sold oat and gone t Farmvilie to live to the regret  their many friends. Mr. He-o l Moorman expects to sell all of hi

document.text: W e have been so fortunate as to spend the past ten days with rela -1 tives and friends in this good old 1 country and have enjoyed anew The good old time befo de war. I It wbh a novel, though most ageable sensation to be so far from I the railroad that we could not bear the train blow, and the vespite was most beneficial to tired nerves. At Pamplins we spent several hours most delightfully with thej family of Rev. W. E. Warren and Dr. and Mr. C. S. Morton, friends of other days. The drive from Pamplins over beyond Putneys was very pleasant, but we missed the mail boxes along the way. Crops  of all kir.ds are good, especially to bacco and fruit abundant. One lady said there had been over a hundred bushels of peaches gat bar -1 ed from her orchard, and every -1 w h ere such quantities of beautifull flowers we never saw. It was our I good pleasure to be just in time fori th e dedication of the new house of I worship of the Douglas Presbyte-I rian church. It is indeed a beuuti-l ful building and reflects great cred -1 it on the architect, Mr. Frank Allen of Tredway. He is an elder in the church and did roost of the work himself. This good old county is I the very plant bed of Presbyteri an, and of all the host of people we met, we shook hands with only four Baptsts and one Methodist. It was a saddened joy to sit in that vast congregation and look aiound in search of familiar faces,II and there were very few whom we recognisedthe boys and girls with whom we bad had such goodtimesl twenty-eight years ago are staid I men and women now with grown I children, and in some cases grand children, around them, and the hair that was once brown or black I is now streaked with grey. We felt a stranger in a strange land ! But when we visited them in their I home it came to us afresh that! Though sundered far by faith w ell meet around one common mercy   Beat. It was a blessed privilege to meet I with Mrs. Letitia McDearmon, Allen I the last of the old McDearmon I family of Appomattox. She has! raised a large familyeight sons I and five daughters, all members of I the Presbyterian churoh and are! filling positions of trust and re -1 responsibility in the church and I county. She is in her 83d year, I and is quite feeble, and as we held! her trembling hand at parting we I thought it would not be long be -1 fore she would hear the Well done I of her Master, whom she has sol faithfully served and enter into her reward. At Felden, near Hampden Sidney we enjoyed meeting with Sargeant Rchard Allen, who served all through the Mexican and Civil wars It was indeed a treat to listen to his reminiscences. He is in his 83d year and is still very fond of hunt ing. We heard much in praise of Dr. McAllister, the new president of Hampden Sidney, and it is thought the number of students at the col lege will largely exceed that of last year. At Prospect we met with an old Appomattox friend, Mrs. Wm. Lew is. How our tongues did fly as we talked of the past, present and fu ture, and all too soon we heard the train that was to take us home. There are other things we would like to write about, but to tell of all the pleasure that was crowded into those ten days would make this letter too long. After all the most pleasant sound we heard while gone was the conductors Evergreen and we realized that in a short while we would be at home, for there is no place like home es pecially if home be in d ar old Ap pomattox.

document.text: U le n f a ll. It is in order to send a letter to the A.  B. T imes , but fear it will ne cessarily be a dull one, as there i nothing going on around here to entertain one. From the number of vehicles that have passed here this a. m. I presume the old county will be well represented at the Courthouse to day. There are several sick persons in our community. Mr. Hunter Mooie is still confined to. his room and Mr. Tom Coleman is ill with fever. Mrs. Gilbert is still sick and feeble and Master Robbie Page is yet an invalid. We hope all of them will soon hi well.  Wheat and oats are looking fair ly well, but owing to dry winds, rain is much needed. It has been said that a cool May insures a good wheat crop. May it be true this time, for we have become acchs- tomed to a small yield of this grain. The monotony of our neighbor hood is occasionally broken by tbe advent of a real estate agent, ac companied possibly by some West ern man, who doubtless wishes to see the couutry and he sees it. Miss Grace Taylor is again a, home after, an absence of many weeks. Sue was accompanied by M ibb Beil Wright, whom we are always glad to welcome in our midst. Mr. Sam Taylor, Jr. ia much im proved in health aud is now at home. Miss Mary Adkinson is visiting relatives in Lynchburg. Mr. Tom Paris made a brief visit to this neighborhood recently. Mrs. Sal lie Hull, of Norfolk visit ed her brother Mr. Richaid Phelps recently. Misses Mary and Stella Abbitt, who have been attending school iu Bedford City, have leturned borne. We hear most fabulous accounts of fish caught m the James, and have enjoyed some of them. We agree to the proposition from An- clersonville, but we must not wait till the fivers get too large, or are all eaten up. The last copy of the T imes was made more enjoyable by the let ters from Anderson vi lie and Wes Dinwiddie, two correspondents who are gifted in more ways than om. Heres a liouquet for your papei one of the best editors iu the state said tbe A.  B. T imes was th. best county paper in the Slate.

document.text: THERE is one way to get along   in any neighborhood without any trouble at all just have nothing to do with any one. But that is not only not a Christian way of living, it is not practicable. You n e e d t h e community a n d the community n e e d s you. If you want to tell the world good- bye, go rent your self a room on the 17th floor of some apartment house in N ew Yor k. You wont be bothered with callers! But if you live in the typical American town or country community, you not only cannot help knowing every body more or less, but you want to know them, you need to know them. -   The Community Includes Everybody QOME communities cease to be communties and become ex- elusive clubs no strangers can brejj in. A lady in a very old county in a long-settled state, said of her next-door neighbor That family came here sixty years ago they don t really belong here. Now a true community ought to include every one in it, and It isnt a real community until it dees. Jesus parable of the sheep and the goats suggests this. The trouble with the goats was that they just never saw the down- and-out members of the community at all. Your own neighborhood has in it, perhaps, some lonely people, unfortunate people, some human left-overs. What is the community doing for them?   The Church and Its Own Q N E practical thing that Chris- tians can do for their commu nities is to see to it that no Chris tian suffers want. However much we may disagree with the Mormons, there iS one feature of the Mormon f1  J hlch tbe rest of us might take to heart in all the depression ox a years ago, there never was a Mormon on relief. Probably in most small com munities the separate congre- gations are not large enough to do this kind of thing effectively Sn7 ly k a community where there are as many as three or four different denom inations, they might all plan n 80 .a whenever any Christian got into a strait, the fff k  Christians would stand by to help him. crJ!ier? wiU alwas be a need for general organizations such as the Red Cross or the Grange and the Community Chest but if Christians always stood by Christians, the rest of the community would at least have less to worry about.    It Takes All Kinds TH E ideal community is one in which everybody is a Christian and indeed all belong to the s a  church. But such communities are few and far between. Most of us live pretty close-and sometimes aren Christ -closeto People who are not Christians, except nerhaDs

the Voters of Appomattox County, Va. I take this method of stating that I am a candidate for the offioe of Treasurer of Appomat tox county for the ensuing term. I submitted my olaims to the Democratic primary, and as I had no opposition in the prima ry I have been declared the nominee of the Democratic party. I therefore solicit the support of every voter in the good old county and promise if elected to discharge the duties of the office in the same manner as I have done heretofore. I wish to thank the people for tbeir past support. R . F . B u r k e .

document.text: The political pot is no sintering but boiling in Buckingham. The friends of George W. 1attesou, A. J. Bondurant and 11. B. Nicholas are pressing the claims of these gentle men for the legislature, and Mt. Paul McKee is aieo a candidate. Wiley J . Huba d. Judge John li. Moss and Paul JobS are candidates before the Democratic primuiy for clerk, and A. 0. Gain tie is the Re publican nominee fo the same office. It is rumored that others still will enter the race And so it goes. Hurrah! for old Buckingham, The old county is alive and active, and is rapidly gr wing in prosperity and wealth. Willard and Mann are both grow mg in strength, li seems as though one or the other will win
